stem: Following an intramuscular injection in the lateral upper arm, a patient has diminished brachioradialis reflex and weakness in wrist extension but intact triceps strength. Which nerve fibers were likely injured?

choices.A: Radial nerve fibers innervating the posterior compartment of the forearm
choices.B: Posterior cord fibers to the axillary nerve
choices.C: Musculocutaneous nerve fibers to the lateral forearm
choices.D: Median nerve fibers to pronator teres
choices.E: Ulnar nerve fibers to flexor carpi ulnaris

rationale_correct: Injury distal to the triceps branches compromises radial nerve fibers supplying brachioradialis and wrist extensors while sparing triceps, indicating radial involvement in the lateral arm.

rationale_distractors.B: Axillary nerve injury would weaken deltoid and teres minor rather than wrist extensors.
rationale_distractors.C: Musculocutaneous nerve lesions affect elbow flexion (biceps) and lateral forearm sensation, not wrist extension.
rationale_distractors.D: Median nerve injury impairs pronation and thenar function.
rationale_distractors.E: Ulnar nerve lesions cause ulnar-sided flexion weakness and intrinsic hand deficits.
